author: makevoid

description.text:
Im a bit tight for space in my room. I wanted to design a simple spool holder that could fit either as a little stand or mount to the side of a wall.
The hub might need a little sanding as ive made it a slightly tight fit on purpose. The hub has a 5mm hole in it for a M5 threaded rod.
The little base, has a 15mm long M5 Nut in it (superglue).
Customized version of http://www.thingiverse.com/thing:406494 Created with Customizer! http://www.thingiverse.com/apps/customizer/run?thing_id=406494
I have been taking the vector-files (Illustrator files) of a series of MakerBot giveaway stickers and reworking them in Inkscape to work well for printing using the MakerBot Unicorn pen plotter.

The "2x" versions of the design files are the ones that print the best. Make sure to "select all" and "explode" the dxf files in QCAD before sending them to the "scribbles.py" script. You can print this on a sticker or a bandana or whatever suits your needs!

author: JamesRX

description.text: This is my project for the final exam of Aeronautical propulsion at the Politecnico of Milan.

All the parts are printed in pla (abs is preferred).
It's important that the infill ratio is higher than 70%, in particular for the rotor. Infact, this component, due to the high centrifugal force, is subject to a very high tensile load.
All the non printed parts are standard ISO metric components. The auxilary components list, are into the gallery as image.
The rotary motion is given by a 700 w grinder.
Customized version of http://www.thingiverse.com/thing:434176 Created with Customizer! http://www.thingiverse.com/apps/customizer/run?thing_id=434176

Using the following options: r = 0.9
nl = 3
nw = 5
iww = 0.6
oww = 1
owh = 30
tl = 104
tw = 102
For Illuminati or Egyptian themed parties, duh. But the openscad file can be modified to make ice cubes in any shape

This should probably be printed upside-down.
The openscad file lets you use any shape for your ice cubes(using import()). Make sure that the object is flat on top of the xy plane at the orgin, and adjust the icecube_size and icecubes appropriately.
I'f your 3D printer is not food safe, then the ice cubes are for decoration only. Or you can try using plastic wrap or something.

title: Ultimaker 1 E3D v6 Bowden mount Version 3 with build-in platform light

description.text:
Improved version of the E3d v6 Bowden mount

  • Things I improved:

  • Raised the E3D v6 Heatsink so the bowden clip fits better
  • Added a bevel capturing the bottom part of the heatsink so the air is not cooling the heater block and temperature rises faster
  • Added a mounting area for the temperature amplifier PCB, which beautifully lights the print bed

Print in ABS only!

  • When using the original UM1 heater block it is so close to the E3D mount that it will melt when printed in PLA.
    Thermocouple Amplifier PCB

  • For the thermocouple amplifier PCB to fit, you have to desolder the two connector and, either solder the wires directly to the PCB, or solder the connectors on the flip side of the PCB, which I did. So you can keep using the connector plug which goes to the UM main board and use the screw-on connector for the Thermocouple.
    .
    My PCB slide's in and is firmly mounted with no additional screws or glue.
    Fan duct

  • I used the same fan duct as previous version, which is indeed close to the heater block as well. Printed already many objects, and had to remove only one drop of melted ABS...
    Heatsink fan

  • See instructions from previous version I made for E3D heatsink fan connection and fan duct.

remixed_from.author: Yvan
remixed_from.title: Prusa i3 Fan Duct for J-Head & Wade - Improved Ver. 3

description.text:
Parts for mounting a common J-head hotend on a RepRapPro Ormerod printer. The fan duct is an adaptation of an existing design, modified with a different mount as well as angling the fan up a bit to make it lighter and smaller. The "cooling ring" has been cut off since it got in the way of the hotend.
It screws into the regular X carriage in place of the stock nozzle mount. The nozzle will be in the same X/Y spot as the original one, but about 20mm further down, which will limit build height. It has mounts for dc42's sensor board, as well as a modified sensor pad for X homing. Since the nozzle and sensor are about 20mm further down relative to the Z carriage, the pad is dropped down as well.
All parts are licensed under CC BY-SA, except the sensor mount which is GNU GPL (in line with the part it is based on).

Print both mounting parts. Attach optional sensor board to side of fan duct, and if you use that for X homing, print and mount the sensor pad. Use two M3x30 screws through the fan duct, past the groove near the top of the J-head nozzle holder, through the nozzle mount and into the nuts in the nut trap in the X carriage.
The "long" fan duct part has elongated holes so it can be adjusted a bit in height.

Hi, awesome design!
would you be willing to release a version fitting the slightly longer E3D-v6 nozzle?

comments.author: Aagaard

comments.text: Very nice! Did you start over with all new geometry?
comments.author: Yvan

comments.text: I started out with your STL, added the mounting bits, and manually changed things around here and there (including cutting off part of the plenum, make a new fan mount at a different angle). The whole "cooling ring" wouldn't fit so I cut that off, but I opened up the entire edge of it.

Dowel to keep aligned the motor of the Y axis.
To tighten the belt, the motor can be twisted causing problems with movement of bed.

Really easy to assemble.
The purpose of the dowel is not damage the motor and soften vibration.
  • Print the piece.
  • Place between the motor and the screw tip. (recomended: screw, printer, nut, dowel).
  • Adjust screw to keep straight the motor shaft.

comments.text: Why would you ever need such thing? It is meant to use a longer bolt and mount the motor to both Y motor parts so it does not twist.
comments.author: Psych0o

comments.text: Yes, it is absolutely true, and also that's the recommended way. BUT that means the distance between the two supports must be exactly the same. That means having a spacer bushes. Also, you'd be subjecting the motor and their bolts to shear stress, which would need to be compensated. The thread of the motor is not designed for any kind of stress (excluding tensile stress), and this will cause vibrations that would damage the motor's rear bearing. So, this system is slightly easier, no? If you want, I could explain the goals of this another (and simpler) method.

title: Soporte para Sony PlayStation Â© Eye (PsEye) para RepRap Prusa 2

description.text:
El mundo de las impresoras 3D es apasionante pero no nos engaÃ±emos, a dÃ­a de hoy todavÃ­a es bastante lento. Muchas veces habrÃ¡s puesto tÃº impresora a trabajar y te habrÃ¡s marchado a dar una vuelta. Sin embargo no estÃ¡s tranquilo porque no sabes si todo estarÃ¡ funcionando como debe. En otras ocasiones te gustarÃ­a compartir tus momentos con otros y hacer un streaming de video. Si ya has tenido estas sensaciones, es posible que ya lo hayas intentado con tu WebCam apoyandola en cualquier sitio improvisado o peor aun orientando la cÃ¡mara de tu portÃ¡til hacia la impresora. El caso es que si no lo pones suficientemente cerca serÃ¡ difÃ­cil que se consiga ver con claridad lo que estÃ¡s imprimiendo.
Para lo primero utilizo TeamViewer http://www.teamviewer.com/es/ un fantÃ¡stico software con el que ademÃ¡s de transmitir video o audio, podrÃ¡s manejar el ordenador donde tengas conectada tu impresora en modo remoto, por ejemplo desde tu telÃ©fono mÃ³vil o desde otro ordenador remoto. En mi caso tenia una PsEye de sobra (la cÃ¡mara utilizada por la PlayStation 3 y que suele venir con los kit para Move). A pesar de que se conecta por USB estÃ¡ cÃ¡mara no dispone de drivers originales de Sony para conectarla a un PC. Sin embargo el grupo CodeLaboratories ha desarrollado entre otras cosas el driver necesario para que funcione en Windows y que se puede descargar en http://codelaboratories.com/get/cl-eye-driver Una vez instalado el driver no necesitas hacer nada mÃ¡s. Ya tendrÃ¡s disponible para elegir en tus aplicaciones como fuente de video y/o audio a tu PsEye.

El soporte estÃ¡ pensado para sujetarlo en alguna de las varillas roscadas M8 de los triÃ¡ngulos equilÃ¡teros. Tan solo necesitas 2 tornillos M4x20, 2 tuercas M4 y opcionalmente 4 arandelas M4. El sistema de sujeciÃ³n del soporte a la impresora es similar al utilizado en las barclamp.
La cÃ¡mara se introduce en la ranura deslizando y es retenida por dos pestaÃ±as flexibles. En caso necesario, la abertura trasera permite empujar para realizar la extracciÃ³n de la cÃ¡mara sin daÃ±arla. En funciÃ³n de la posiciÃ³n que mejor se adapte a la iluminaciÃ³n o distribuciÃ³n de escritorio debes elegir uno de los dos archivos.
  • Las posiciones en color verde corresponden a la pieza 'SoportePSEye XmaxYmin-XminYmax.stl'
  • Las posiciones en color azul corresponden a la pieza 'SoportePSEye XminYmin-XmaxYmax.stl'
    • Recomendaciones al imprimir:
    En el programa de laminado establece al menos 100mm/s para la velocidad de impresiÃ³n en los Bridges. Si te gusta y al final te decides a imprimirlo no te olvides de comentarlo.
    Dispongo de los ficheros CAD por si alguien quiere modificarlos para otros modelos de cÃ¡maras.

Spy head icon from the game "Team Fortress 2"

Two different designs for a box to store 10 DS/3DS games in. The first one is a single part, where the games are secured with a rubber band - hence the notch on the bottom. The second one is two-part, with a base and a slide-on lid. Built with Sketchup, printed with a Replicator 2
[edit] I did some tweaking on the box with lid. Now, you don't have to slide the lid all the way, but rather only the last centimeter. Also, the box is now 2mm smaller than before, and 1mm thinner. Finally, instead of friction on the whole length of the lid, there is now a little "boss" that holds the lid closed.
Everything is optimized towards the toleranced of our makerbot replicator 2. maybe things need to be sandpapered or otherwise modified to create a good, tight fit using other printers.

comments.text: So I printed the base looks awesome, fits the cartridges well. But I also printed the lid, for the base that uses the lid. It slides on great, but the little "boss" notch doesnt seem to lock into anything. So the lid just slides off if you tilt the whole thing at an angle. I can't lift the lid off, which is great. But the slide feature does not secure itself. Any suggestions?
comments.author: mochaotter

remixed_from.title: NUT JOB | Nut, Bolt, Washer and Threaded Rod Factory

description.text: My wife saw something like this in a magazine and asked if I could put my new hobby to use for making something functional! It allows you to hang up to 5 hangers on the wall. Arm will swivel up to get it out of the way when not in use. The nut and bolt were generated using the NUT JOB | Nut, Bolt, Washer and Threaded Rod Factory. The arm will swivel up, but may have problems staying up. I'll work on making it "lock" into place a little better when not in use.

Print one of each piece. The arm is 180mm long, so it could be a squeeze on some platforms. In that case, you may want to try positioning it at a 45-degree angle (give or take 15 degrees). It could also be scaled down to fit but may make inserting the laundry hangers into the holes a little more difficult. I would also recommend printing the bracket vertically (as it is displayed in the picture). I'm afraid the pull of a heavy arm might cause some layer separation and break the bracket. And nobody wants clean laundry on the floor.
  • Mount the bracket to the wall to a stud (preferably) or using wall anchors and screws.
  • Insert the arm into the bracket, making sure the small holes of the bracket and arm line up.
  • Push the bolt into the small holes through the bracket and arm.
  • Screw the nut onto the bolt. Make sure it is not too tight or it could break the nut or bolt, or it could make it harder to swivel the arm up.
  • Do your laundry.

description.text:
This is a new building block toy with a unique connectable system. This is designed for 3D pixel art and to rival Lego. This may even evolve into a building set for a popular video game that uses cubes to build structures. The main focus is minimal block types with unlimited potential. This set includes, the base block, half block, quarter block, panel, C-Clip, L-Clip, T-Clip, and clear block.
The panel can be customized with printed stickers and interchangeable or stickers can be placed on the Base Block to be permanent.
Half Block and Quarter Block can be used in construction and as a base floor.

This has yet to be made. The measurements may need to be adjusted for the final product. I want to design the clips as one item with a ball joint in the middle so that it can be rotated to the angle desired instead of 3 separate pieces, but my skills are limited right now. This will make it a minimalist design but with unlimited potential.

description.text: Small extruder for direct drive motor with planetary gear. 3mm filament.

All I have so far is the servo holders. Parallax Continuous rotation servos are what give Mark his mobility, and I needed an L-bracket to mount them. So, I made this thing. Updates will come.

description.text: Wall mount for ear muffs (and safety glasses). Also for headphones.

Print two of them. Be carefull when tightening screws. They can easily delaminate the layering if you tighten to much/to fast. You have to select the "grain" direction where you want the strength to be. I printed these laying down on their side like in the picture. Figured that is where the load will be. A few extra layers will probably not hurt either.  
Model has a 55mm (2.165 inches) gap between the two protusions on the top. But of course you can scale to whatever you need. Measure your headgear before printing.  
Tip: Mount these above shoulder height or in a spot where you don't accidentally ram into them with your shoulder.

Wemade this test to show the users of desktop 3D printers that they do not always need high resolution files to get a good result. This high definition 3D scan of a hand was reduced by almost 50 times its original mesh density, without affecting the 3D printed result.

comments.text: There is a thing http://www.thingiverse.com/thing:31581 as a base that I use for making my molds. For it to work your mesh needs to be 100% manifold with no unbound edges or duplicate faces. I generally load the mesh in Meshlab, do quadratic edge fold to decimate down to ~15K faces and then render Boundry edges and non-manifold edges and faces so I can see where all the errors are and then I fix them by hand in Sketchup. I can make a mold of the cat next myself if you'd like (this one right? http://www.thingiverse.com/thing:440876) it'll probably take me awhile though, there are over 100 problems with the mesh, probably can do it for next week some time though.

comments.text: I've printed the "little snap in part" several times now and it always breaks on me. I'm using your version 2 with PLA. Any suggestions? I really want to use this.
comments.author: ignisuti

comments.text: Unless your'e using some of the newer PLA blends with additives, you cant expect PLA to take in much mechanical stress reliably. And some PLA brands are more brittle than others. This is a good time to use ABS or even better, Nylon. Polycarbonate should also give you good results. I haven't used HIPS or HDPE but I believe they can also take in more bending so it should work.

Little command line program to convert gcode files that specify flow rate in PWM to gcode files that specify flow rate in RPM. Sorry - Windows only.
If you do not have a stepper extruder, you do not need this Thing.

Unpack rpmify.exe to a directory somewhere in your PATH. The C# source and project file are included too but you can toss those if you don\'t want to poke at the source.
  • open a command prompt
  • type: rpmify (gcode file) (max RPMs)
    -- (gcode file) is the gcode file to convert. Make sure to enclose it in quotes if it contains spaces
    -- (max RPM) is the maximum RPM value for your stepper extruder
  • the resulting will have the extension \".rpm.gcode\" so, for example, \"MyThing.gcode\" will get converted to \"MyThing.rpm.gcode\"
  • example: rpmify "my cool object.gcode" 15
    • Bonus points: rewrite in Java or something more portable!

Simplify3D and Cura slicer did not slice it perfectly and you could see holes, if you use the slic3r program it should be good.

happy printing

description.text:
Thunderbird 2
Made with Green, Yellow, Red, White, Black, Silver & Natural PLA
From the TV series by Gerry Anderson

I used the Standard profile to print on a Replicator2
Part Name Plastic used Print time
Green- Front 48g 3.0 hrs
Green- Rear 23g 1.5 hrs
Green- center 86g 5.25 hrs
Green- Tailplane 17g 1.5 hrs
Green- wings 8g 45 min
Yellow- front_center partition 13g 30 min
yellow- engine front section 5g 20 min
Yellow- engine ring 4g 10 min
Black- Bottom rollers 3g 8 min
Black- Engine inlet 1g 5 min
Black- Rear engine insert 2g 5 min
Black- Tailplane center front inserts 3g 10 min
Black- rear engine section 5g 20 min
Black- Tailplane end inserts 1g 5 min
White- Figures 5g 15 min
Red- Engine_tail 13g 55 min
Grey- Engine baffle 2g 5 min
Transparent- Windows 2g 8 min
How to get yellow stripes on the wings using Green and yellow PLA.
This tip assumes you are printing 1 set of Green- Wings with rafts enabled.
Start the print using Green PLA
At 77% complete Change filament to Yellow
At 82% Change to Green
At 86% Change to Yellow
At 92% Change back to Green to finish the print

H2 = BASE HEIGHT
N = NUMBER OF FLEXIBLE ELEMENTS
D3 = SCREW HOLE DIAMETER
Dnut = NUT HOLE DIAMETER
Hnut = NUT HOLE THICKNESS

i'm still working to improve strength of the motor zone, the legs and reduce the arms flexibility. it crashed many times, i broke some props and legs but is still alive :D

comments.text: Great platform design! I ended up sanding with rough, then fine grit sandpaper, followed by primer (Krylon spray) and it created a fairly smooth surface. For those scaling up to 5.9 inches, you will begin to see the "mesh", which can't be sanded out. If you want it to have really nice curves you'll have to modify the model to insert extra vertices. I used craft acrylic paints and finished it off with 2 coasts of acrylic varnish (Liquitex). First a gloss, which is really easy to tell if you missed a spot... followed by a second layer of gloss and matte, depending on spot areas I wanted glossy or matte. BEWARE using spray finish as the acetone does not play well with acrylics and you'll end up with a sticky/tacky toy.

title: RepRapDiscount Graphic Smart Controller angled case for Rigidbot

description.text:
This LCD controller cover is specifically for mounting on Rigidbot. It is designed for RepRap Graphic Smart Controller available from http://reprap.org/wiki/RepRapDiscount_Full_Graphic_Smart_Controller. The base plate screws on Rigidbot frame and securely holds display at 0, 30 and 60 degrees.
A better case for this LCD is available from http://www.thingiverse.com/thing:87250 and has dozens of variants, if you are looking for non-Rigidbot application.
The back and front cover does not have screw holes to accommodate for PCB variations and should be drilled after marking. To mount it to frame, I drilled with 3/16" and used 4-40 tap and 1/2" machine screws.
Rhino 5 model included. Instructions on how to install LCD module to Rigidbot board: http://rigidtalk.com/wiki/index.php?title=LCD_Smart_Controller.

Front cover can be printed at higher resolution (0.16), back and plate can be rough (0.20)
Print backcover and support plate with 100% infill.
Print 4 screw spacers which go between LCD module and backplate.

description.text:
Gizmo dorks conductive black ABS.
The filament ink was tested on 12 volts to 110 volts and at 5000 volts.
This ink is soft and seems to have a lower melting point than the typical ABS due to a thermo-conductively enhanced state.
This material needs to be purged for over 20 cm3 before trying another color unless utilizing a "fade in" affect on the next lighter print(s).
Buying this awesome Conductive 3D Printer Ink from Gizmo Dorks was a good choice for starters. If you were someone who also missed the memo on product specifics: We tested this product without a heated bed. This conductive filament stuck to the taped bed easily at 175C Do try some for less than $99 to show that there is a demand for printing circuits.
Happily supplying you with interesting and helpful public domain.
Thanks to all of our supporters, thanks to Thingiverse, and thank you for checking into the future of conductive 3-D printing.
Rhino 5

Oh yes, thank you for your questions, I believe something like india ink and glue. The conductive filament seems to have thermodynamic characteristics of a metal and could be a better heat sink design. I had to lower the temperature to my lowest setting @ 175C and have a "special" bed with heat; otherwise anyone with PLA capabilities can expect to print this stuff. There were some unusual bubbles on the roll of ink, besides that I would send you with confidence to Gizmo Dorks for this "Saturating Black" that you might want to purge before changing color.
The Neon Light Power Supply is designed to detect a short and power down. I touched it and got some tingles but no burns.

title: Imperial & Metric Nut Size Checker / Gauge

description.text:
Printable gauges that you can press-fit hex nuts into and use to check your bolt collection. You could leave bolts in as well and then check both nuts & bolts. There is a 7.5mm tall recess below each row of openings for fixing labels. For Imperial, the gauge is designed for the following nuts:
6-32, 8-32, 10-24, 10-32, 1/4"-20
1/4"-28, 5/16"-18, 5/16"-24, 3/8"-16, 3/8"-24
7/16"-14, 7/16"-20, 1/2"-13, 1/2"-20 For Metric, the gauge is designed for the following nuts:
M2x0.4, m2.5x0.45, M3x0.5, M4x0.7, M5x0.8
M6x1.0, M8x1.0, M8x1.25, M10x1.0, M10x1.25 Each gauge is less than 100mm wide so they should be printable on just about every printer. EDIT Jan 23, 2013: Sorry folks. The MetricNutSizeChecker.STL file that was initially uploaded was the wrong version. The correct one is posted now. EDIT Jan 25, 2013: Information on nut dimensions was obtained from:
http://www.engineershandbook.com/Tables/nuts.htm
  • and -
    http://www.fairburyfastener.com/xdims_metric_nuts.htm
I printed mine with 50% fill, 0.4mm width, and 0.25mm layer height.  The nuts are a tight press fit and did not require glue.

description.text:
These are the plastic parts for the Estes GeoSat LV classic model rocket.  The Satellite is broken up into three pieces for ease of printing.  The nose cone is also included.  The nose and tailcones for the twin boosters will be made available soon.  I'm waiting for exact measurements to be made available.  This is only the plastic parts to recreate the kit.  Other things like paper tubes and balsa fins are needed.  
Update 9/1/2014

I've added the parts for the booster nose cone and tail cone.  The tail cone prints as two pieces and is assembled using a small piece of 1/2" wood dowel.  
Update 9/5/2014
I've Tweaked the booster nose cone a bit based on comparisons with the original part.  It's a tiny bit less blunt now.

The Satellite requires a short piece of 1/2" dowel to assemble the top two thirds. The same goes for the booster tail cone pieces.
Full plans and instructions for building this classic kit are available here:
http://www.spacemodeling.org/jimz/est1977.htm

remixed_from.author: bsthomps
remixed_from.title: Prusa Spool Holder and Support for 1kg Spools

description.text:
Remixed from http://www.thingiverse.com/thing:45930
Topology optimization with topy: https://code.google.com/p/topy/
Video of the optimization process: http://youtu.be/LTsEBuIUHTA
Updated: dxf and scad files, smoothed and thresholded to get a nicer part. I like the quick release version by mrwolfe too, so I added an stl in that style.

Basic workflow for doing this toppology optimized part:
  • Define solid and void regions. For this part the void regions are the holes for smooth rod of the reprap and the rod that supports the spool.
  • Define boundary and load conditions. I defined the part to be pinned at the rod closest to the spool. Downward forces at the spool, as well as downward forces at the rod furthest from the spool. This second set of forces is scaled to roughly blance the moment around the pinned rod.
  • Run topology optimization in topy; see the tutorial.
  • Smooth topy output in gimp, trace the bitmap in inkscape, and then export a dxf.
  • Import the dxf into openscad, cut the holes so they are nice and round (the smoothing step will smear them a bit). Do any other CAD clean-up in openscad.
  • Export stl.
  • Slice and print!
Kind of hard to print, need to sink Z about 3mm

I would like to present the latest advancement in "shoot bees that are slightly too far away" technology.  The Spray Extender is a can-to-stick adapter for a regular size 18oz can of bee/wasp/hornet killer.  It features a lever over the top of the can to operate the spray button.  The user pulls on a piece of fishing line tied to the lever to actuate the spray button.  
Pretty simple. Very effective.

.rsdoc files can be opened and edited in DesignSpark Mechanical.  (it's a free 3D design program, google it)  
There are 2 parts to print, the can_cap and the trigger_arm.  
A 4-40 1/2" long screw can be used to secure the trigger_arm to the can_cap.  
A 10' long 1/2" electrical conduit is used as the pole.  It is a friction fit that worked fine for me.  
I used some "Omniflex Braid" fishing line that I had lying around.  Tie one end to the trigger_arm.  thread it through the rectangular block on the side of the can_cap directly below the trigger_arm.  You want to thread it through the top and out the side so that it comes back towards the user.  
A hose clamp is used to secure the can to the can_cap.

title: Weep Hole Cap
license: Creative Commons - Attribution - Non-Commercial - Share Alike

description.text:
There were quite a few mud packers in the weep holes on my brand new house so I needed a way to cover them up. Home Depot wanted a dollar a piece for these ugly massive rectangular weep hole covers. No way.  
So I fired up OpenSCAD and designed these, which I calculate to cost about two to three cents a piece, and printed them in sets of 25 on my new Prusa Mendel in white PLA.  
These fit into my house's weep holes quite nicely with a small amount of weather resistant silicone around them.

First of all, measure the approximate size of the weep holes on your house, then plug in appropriate values to the openscad file.  
I would recommend printing these in plates of about 20-25.  
To install these, get a tube of weather resistant silicone or caulk, and apply a fair amount around the cap. Check the weep hole is clear of pests, then insert to be flush with the mortar.  
It should fit somewhat loose but the silicone/caulk will set and harden.

It sounds like it will then.
just print the upper and lower halves of the main cassette. Glue them together.
Then take out your ashtray and press out the section holding the cig lighter so you have one empty rectangle in the dash.
Press the cig lighter into the printed section until it clicks in much like it did to the OEm and then push the entire cassette assembly back into the dash.
It will lock in at each end behind little tabs that are part of the BMW dashboard just inside the opening of the ashtray cavity.
If that all fits then your home and hosed to continue the rest. Use a small screwdrive to release the spring end I made and the fixed end will come past the tab on its own if the pull the cassette out slightly sideways.

author: Afrokid

description.text:
It's designed for FUTABA 10C transmitter.
Use two 3mm tapping screw to secure it on the transmitter handle.

The FlashForge Dreamer X Axis Carriage is a replacement carriage for the carriage that ships with the FlashForge Dreamer. It does not currently contain the X axis belt clamp. You can use the original X axis belt clamp, or you can print the X axis belt clamp benird created that's found here: http://www.thingiverse.com/thing:456853 PRINT THIS BEFORE YOU NEED IT! The older model Dreamers that don't have the clear door and the cooling fans on the back unfortunately can sometimes get too hot when printing with the lid on causing the X axis carriage to melt slightly and deform. They were great printers except for that serious flaw. The newer printers with the clear door and cooling fans on the back should not have this problem. My original X axis carriage MELTED when doing dual extrusion with the Dreamer. I was printing ABS at 230 C with the build platform at 105 C, and the dreamer's lid on. I got a free replacement carriage from FlashForge and then decided to design and print a backup just it case it too melted. And shortly thereafter it did melt. Until I added my own custom thermostat controlled cooling fan system, I had to print without the lid on to avoid melting the X axis carriage. Anyway, print this BEFORE this happens to your printer. That way you have a back up just in case it happens to your printer. I am currently using this X carriage for all my printing on my Dreamer. I have a few backups just in case. It's been working great for many months. I designed this from scratch using Blender. I included the original Blender source file so you can easily tweak it using Blender.

DO NOT PRINT THIS WITH PLA! Print it with plastic that's resistant to higher temperatures than PLA. I recommend printing this X carriage using BLACK ABS. Why black? It typically melts at a higher temperature than other colors of ABS. I use HIPS as the support material for it when printing it. I use 50% infill for strength and at least 3 shells. HIPS support can be easily removed by hand because it doesn't fuse to the ABS.

comments.author: APCTUS

comments.text:
Are there any tips that would prevent the Carriage from melting?
From what I understand, the 2 extruders are mounted to an aluminium block. The small heatsinks with fans are supposed to keep the aluminium block from becoming too hot and melt the plastic. On my machine I put some heatsink compound between the small heatsinks and the aluminium block to maximise heat transfer. Also I have heard that this can happen if you switch off your machine directly after printing - not allowing the fans to cool down the aluminium block sufficiently.
comments.author: CyberMosfet

comments.text: SOME DREAMER PRINTERS DO NOT HAVE THIS PROBLEM! They include cooling fans on the back of the printer that draw in cool air from the outside of the printer when the internal temperature gets too hot. My printer didn't have these cooling fans on the back. Many people, like me, have Dreamer printers that lack the cooling fans on the back. They were removed by FlashForge to save cost. As far as I am aware, the latest version of the Dreamer has the fans on the back, and they are thermostatically controlled. If you have this version, you don't need to worry about the X carriage melting.

This is an enclosure for covering the mains voltage and output connections of a standard 12V 300W fanless power supply such as can be readily purchased via eBay, for use with Ormerod 1 or other 3D printer. It has cutouts for a switched and fused mains inlet, 20A output connector, and indicator neon.

The parts that fit the holes in this enclosure are: Power supply: 12V 300W regulated power supply, available from several eBay UK suppliers
Snap-in switched and fused IEC mains inlet: Maplin N94CZ
Mains neon: Maplin BK54J
20A Neutrik connector: I used Maplin N55GB with mating plug N54GB, but Maplin now sells the official "power out" version which is A52QQ with mating plug A48QQ, so I recommend those instead A modification I suggest is to countersink the screw hole on the right hand side. Using a countersunk screw there allows you to stand the PSU on its side, taking up less desk space. You can get IEC mains inlets that incorporate the neon as well as the switch and fuse, for example Bulgin BZH01/Z0000/02, is available from Farnell and elsewhere. Using one of these would simplify the mains wiring, but you would need to adjust the cutout size in my design. The Neutrik connector part numbers are NAC3MPB-1 with mating plug NAC3FCB, also available form Farnell.

title: Ormerod nozzle mount for 1- or 2-nozzle print heads

description.text: This is a customizable nozzle mount for the Ormerod printer. You can choose whether it is the same width as the standard Ormerod nozzle mount, or the wider version to support dual-nozzle print heads. You can have 1, 2 or 3 slots in it for the Bowden filament tubes. You can also configure the mounting angle of the print head, to compensate for any tendency of the head to sag. And you can choose a long version to help keep the x-carriage and other printer parts cooler when printing ABS.

Open the .scad file in OpenScad, edit the parameters at the top of the file according to your requirements, press F6 to render, and export the STL. The two pre-made STL files are for dual-nozzle printer heads, or single-nozzle heads with the wider heatsink block. See http://miscsolutions.wordpress.com/2014/07/27/converting-the-reprappro-ormerod-to-dual-colour/ for details of the dual nozzle Ormerod conversion.

I tried again in ABS, increased the hot end tempreature from 230 to 245, and bed from 110 to 115 and set speed to 30 mm/s, to try to reduce warping and cracks, and downscaled by 0.7 factor. In Cura I selected both support and raft, and the estimated printing time was about 10 hours.
In general it is printing well, however, the back teeth of the upper mandible were kick away by the hotend, because warping lifted the back ends, but printing continued with some speguetti that I'll be able to clean up afterwards.
I see that the support material added by Cura is not working as well as it should. I see that the voronoi version ( http://www.thingiverse.com/thing:518748 ) has some "organic" pillars (not vertical but tilted) that work very well, and teeth remain where they are supposed to be. The hexagonal ends go through the holes, and you push the square ends. These now have extra length so that they can also be used with my Duet + X4 enclosure.

title: Fan Backwash eliminator and finger guard for Ormerod hot end

description.text: The fan on the Ormerod hot end produces a lot of backwash. This backwash eliminator is based on a design by kwikius (Andy), which I have modified to make it thin enough to allow the hot end to slide behind the Duet enclosure on the Ormerod 1. It is held in place by 50mm countersunk screws instead of the original clips. You can either use just 2 screws (which replace the original 2 screws used to hold the fan, heatsink block, heatsink and plastic parts together), or you can drill 2 more holes in the heatsink and use 4 screws, with nyloc nuts on the ends of the upper 2 screws..

description.text: Large size Hugo Name for printing

This simple robot will one day soon play the maracas! On top of a cylindrical form will be a tray for holding dried beans and such. The tray rotates and reverses direction to create MaracaBot music. Inside the base and tray is a planetary gear set for multiplying torque and a weak but sufficiently torquey little 3D printed stepper motor.
I did get the plastic 3D printed stepper motor to work but just barely and now I have added wood screw cores to really focus the magnetic field, strengthening the motor a bit. It will still be weak but the thing is its nearly 100% plastic so you can print a zillion of them if you want at a cost of about ten bucks each.
MaracaBot! I'm printing mine already, we shall se if it works...
p.s. working on a better, cheaper bot that you will enjoy more!
Les p.s. since this design I have printed some Gear Toys (see my page to find Gear Toy 1 and Gear Toy 2). I learned enough about planetary gear systems to possibly make this design work with a few changes. Well, best would be a total redesign but the principle is basically the same: 3D printed stepper motor driven by custom electronics and planetary gears to multiply torque, rotating a maracas chamber. The one change i'd make in the motor is to use a larger diameter rotor to increase the raw motor torque. Rawr! So you see I'm still on it just had to take an experiential detour. MaracaBot will one day walk the earth, you just wait!

comments.text: I'm having a change of heart as to whether it is beneficial to complete the Maracabot project as is.  It may be cheaper and easier to use a small hobby DC motor for this.  In fact, that might be way better, perhaps time for a redesign.  There are over 2k views on it already (at this time) so the popularity of it makes me think I'd better make some form of Maracabot or other musical instrument for y'all to build!  I think the DC motor approach might be best...  Could I get some feedback from anyone following this design?

title: Spacers for iamburny's Y-axis belt clamp

description.text: iamburny's Y-belt clamps solve one of the problems of the Ormerod 1 design. However, another problem is that the Y belt length is only adjustable in units of the MXL belt tooth pitch, which is too large to allow proper adjustment of the tension. This is a set of 3 shims of different thickness, designed to slip under the y-belt clamps. Use them singly or in combination to get the belt tension just right.

description.text:
This is a modified version of the original toothpaste squeezer 63mm. This one has a locking mechanism.
This thing was made with Tinkercad. Edit it online https://tinkercad.com/things/cJlSVVqUCEe

This is an update to the original toothpaste squeezer 63mm. This one has an added lock that keeps the tube from unwinding. It is best to use this apparatus after you have squeezed out about 1/4 of the tube to help it get a good start.
As shown by the layout diagram it is usually best to print most of this one with the parts standing on end to avoid having to use supports. So far it has printed "OK". Here is a video of how it works (https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=_ks2lySTKB8&feature=youtu.be).
The squeezer is easily assembled (the original was printed all as one piece which while cool sometimes was difficult to get the pieces apart) by using the clips made for the inside of the body and the outside end piece.
To assemble simply slide the turning rod through the body assembly and use the large clip to slide into the slot just on the inside of the body nearest the adjusting gear.
Put the other clip on the outside end of the turning rod (this part isn't as necessary since the inside clip holds it all, but I just thought it would add a little support).
Place the small pin through the lock and with the lock facing the gear and the hole portion of the lock facing downward, push the pin into the small hole located on the edge of the body just outside the area of the gear.
Load your tube from the outside of the body through the 63mm slot, and align the inside rod slot with the body slot and push the tube through both slots. When the tube protrudes slightly through the rod slot you can begin turning the gear knob in a clockwise motion to wrap the tube on the rod. Flip the lock toward the gear and let it fall between each of the gear teeth as you adjust to hold tension on the tube and prevent it from unwinding.

description.text:
I wanted an oiler to stop/reduce clogging, but wanted it near the spool to stop the spool from sometimes continuously unspooling filament with the slight friction caused by the sponge/cloth.
My remix has slightly thinner walls and base, and is slightly shorter to reduce the required filament.
  • Printed in PLA, 3 perimeters/top/bottom.
  • Threaded onto wire coat hanger which is then hooked onto my spool rod.
  • I cut and folded some chux cloth to insert into the holder then added 3 drops of cooking oil. The sponge used in the original version would be better but I didn't have any on hand.
  • Thread filament and start printing.
    • I will probably shorten my wire so the oiler is closer to to spool but it'll so for now. The oiler is free to slide from side to side on the wire and the wire can swing back and forward if needed.

author: Harebourg

title: Parametric dual motor syringe with enhanced design - Imperial College London

description.text:
//UPDATED 21/9/14: Syringe holder adjusted to make motor holder more rigid and to move the syringe body lip closer to the piston lip.// A single motor syringe was tried and tested, we found that it was inadequate for high accuracy and precision situations. Pulling and pushing assymetrically adjacent to the syringe body caused flexing and strain in the piston holder. This design provides two motors pulling/pushing either side of the syringe, to eliminate flexing and increase reliability and power available.
We have successfully used this with glass syringes to reduce non specific adsorption of reagents to the syringe wall.
The design is mostly parametric and we be further modified to include more relevant parameters of interest to the user.

This design uses NEMA 17 motors, the longer the motor the more torque and the less likely stalls will be.
We connect this to a RAMPS or sanguinololu, they are connected to the stepper chips controlling the extruders. A single stepper can control both motors by splicing the cables. Most steppers can provide 2a, enough for the majority of NEMA 17 motors.
Different length syringes are applicable through changing the SCAD code for different lip styles.

comments.text: Why not use just one motor and connect the shafts with a chain or belt? That way you need not rely on two motors working.
comments.author: Smoutech

comments.text: The Prusa 3D printer uses a similar tactic for the Z axis, there is not a problem with the motors not working with spliced cables. I believe doing it with two motors also affords more torque; this seems to be important for glass syringes especially.
comments.author: Smoutech

comments.author: quadmodder

comments.text:
Hello, A friend of mine has made one (the one on the picture) but he cannot print due to hot end issue (he broke his).
But so far the mechanical aspect of the printer is fine.
The 3030 aluminum extrusion are very strong and and you have several possibilities for the square holders.
you can print some (http://www.thingiverse.com/thing:526259) or get metal ones.
I have metal ones and they are great.
If you hold the whole chassis up in the air and then hit the printer chassis with something, the whole stuff resonates. When you lay a finger on any part of the chassis while resonating everything stops immediately.
To me this is a pretty good thing meaning that every piece are hold tight and very rigid.
comments.author: quadmodder
